comments.author: Sarah
comments.content: This looks absolutely delicious!  Unfortunately, my husband is allergic to alcohol so using red wine is out.  Can you suggest any alternatives?  I'd love to make a modified version.  Thanks!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Sure, you could deglaze this with a clear vegetable broth instead, and then use a small amount of lemon juice to add some acidity (or verjus or balsamic vinegar if the alcohol content in those is low enough to avoid giving him a problem). Or to go a another way, add 1 cup of tomato puree, which will give you the acid and flavor depth, but a somewhat different dish.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Nope... Calabro, which is an old-school brand and my favorite, lists as ingredients: whole milk, starter, touch of salt. Typically when folks make it at home they use a little vinegar or lemon juice instead of a starter to coagulate it.

This is a wonderful sauce, and yes, a video of making the pasta will be very interesting and educational.

Have you ever tried making ricotta at home any time, without using rennet?

thanks..

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey PB - indeed, I have made my own ricotta a few times. I've found it to be good, but not *as* good as the best commercial ricotta I know (Calabro, or for those in Seattle, the store-made stuff at DeLaurenti). It is however *much* better than typical grocery store ricotta, which I find to be grainy and lacking in the pure dairy sweetness of the good stuff.
